history.content:
In the scope of Econ/CS/Math, Stat 20 is somewhat of a waste of time, since it covers so little of the relevant topics in those fields. I would definitely take Stat 134.

Stat 134 covers more topics in probability than CS 70, so if you take 134 after 70 it would be a bit easier. CS 170 + Stat 134 + Econ 101A sounds like a nightmare in one semester.

Yes, CS 70 is enough to prepare for upper div. CS courses. If you're interested in CS 188/189/Machine Learning stuff, I would highly recommend Stat 134 and even Stat 135 if you have the time in your schedule, since AI/ML is very rooted in probability.

In the scope of Econ/CS/Math, Stat 20 is somewhat of a waste of time, since it covers so little of the relevant topics in those fields. I would definitely take Stat 134.

Yes, CS 70 is enough to prepare for upper div. CS courses. If you're interested in CS 188/189/Machine Learning stuff, I would highly recommend Stat 134 and even Stat 135 if you have the time in your schedule.

children.subject: +1 Thanks Sinho!  I'm optimistic to hear there may be a shift to make EE126 more "broadly useful for many students" vs. predominantly honors students only.

The topics that Stat 134 will cover in addition to CS 70 are: a few more continuous distributions (beta, gamma), more continuous probability (change of variables; sums of distributions), bivariate Gaussian, and perhaps de Moivre's theorem (which proves that the binomial distribution converges to the normal distribution). In terms of topics alone, there is significant overlap. The primary benefit is that Stat 134 has more time to spend on the concepts, so you will most likely get a better understanding of, e.g., joint distributions and joint densities.

The topics that EE 126 will likely cover in addition to CS 70 are: convergence of random variables, Chernoff bound, sums of distributions, moment generating functions, Poisson process, PageRank, Kalman filter, hidden Markov models, Viterbi algorithm, EM algorithm, some statistics (MLE/MAP/Bayesian estimators; hypothesis testing, Neyman-Pearson), multivariate Gaussian.
Other topics covered last semester: some information theory (coding, erasure channels), random graphs, other topics in Markov chains (reversible Markov chains, continuous-time Markov chains).

EE 126 is designed to be more application-centric.

Please don't be scared to take EE 126. Apparently you did very well in CS 70, so you have adequate preparation for EE 126. Anyway, EE 126 is not intended to be difficult for the sake of being difficult. Of course, probability theory can be made arbitrarily hard if you make it so; but I believe the key ideas of the course can be intuitive and simple and that's what we're hoping to convey. I understand that EE 126 has an intimidating reputation. I have talked with some of the EE 126 professors and they want to make the course broadly useful for many students, instead of tailoring the course for a small, elite group of students.

Anyway, to answer your question about whether it's common to take a second probability course: it depends, of course, on what you want to do. "Big data" is really popular at the moment so many students seem to do a CS/Stat combo.

history.content:
I am an incoming sophomore intending to double major in CS and ECON and currently deciding between taking STAT 20 or STAT 134 next semester. I initially chose to take STAT 20 next semester, but now I am a little bit hesitated since STAT 20 seems to have the same content as AP Statistics and some people told me that STAT 134 is useful for CS major.

Is STAT 134 worth taking for CS major? How useful is it (Ex. Is it useful for data science/machine learning)? How much more does it covers beyond CS 70? Will it still be very hard after CS 70? I'm thinking of taking CS 170 and ECON 101A next semester, so I don't want to spend too much time on it (For reference: Got an A in CS 70 this semester with Rao).

I've heard EECS 126 is more suitable for CS major, but I probably won't take it since I'm afraid that the curve will be bad because only top EECS students would choose to take it. Also, what does EECS 126 covers beyond CS 70? Does it covers STAT 134?

Also, is CS 70 enough preparation for further CS courses? Do CS majors generally take a second course in probability?

Can someone please help me with it? Thank you so much!
